text: I’m a runner.

I’ve been running
since I was 10.
I’ve always been fast.

Almost four years
ago, at 45, I

decided to medically
transition from male
to female.
It’s been hard.

“— fundamentally unfair for
men to compete in women’s
sports.”

“The new target is
transgender kids —”
“— war on women.”

“These bills do uphold white
supremacy under the guise —”

“This bill protects
our students.”

Running probably
saved my life.
It’s been my sanctuary.

“You know, girls are going
to play girls’ sports.

And boys are going to
play boys’ sports.”

“This is legislative
bullying, plain and simple.”

“Can’t just decide you’re
a woman and compete with
women.”

“With this movement, then
you are not on the right side
of history.”

Since I started
running as a woman,
something surprised me.

After hormone therapy, I
thought I would slow down.

But I’ve actually gotten
faster compared to women
my age.

I now break women’s records
regularly in my workouts.

Fairness is a difficult thing
to come about in sports.

Some people just have
biological advantages.

I didn’t want to be
rejected by my family.

So that idea of transition was
really not an option in 2016,
when I attempted suicide.

And I didn’t want to be an
embarrassment to my family,
my friends.

I didn’t want to have to
have them explain to people,

“Oh, yeah, Andie’s this man
who’s becoming a woman.”

I didn’t want to have
them go through that.

And I was very
concerned for them,

that I thought taking my
life was a better choice.

And my doctor, who was just my
doctor in the emergency room,

said, “You know, your
parents would rather

have a live trans
daughter than a dead son.”
And that stuck.

Odds are, if you’re
watching this,

you have your mind made up if
I belong in women’s sports.

But I want to form my
views based on science.

The first and
most widely cited

study on elite
trans athletes says

if I use hormone
therapy for one year,
I can compete as a woman.
There’s a catch, though.

This prevailing study is
based on just eight people.

That’s all the transgender
female runners the researcher
could track down at the time.

There aren’t many
of us out there.

“Transgender athlete bans
introduced in 31 states.”

“Transgenders participating
in women’s sports will destroy
women’s sports.”

“Bills are being introduced
and advanced at the state

level about
transgender youth, too.”

A bill targeting youth
athletes has been proposed
right here in Minnesota.

“In Minnesota, the proposed
legislation will actually

make it a misdemeanor
for a transgender athlete

to participate in
women’s sports.”

But bans ostracized
trans kids further.

The number of trans athletes
like me is minuscule.

And overall, we’re far from
dominating anything athletic.

The current political campaign
in America against trans

athletes like me isn’t
about sports at all.

It’s about
discrimination and fear.

It has nothing to
do with science.
I was a wound-up child.

And my dad took me out
running to relieve stress.

I said I had the best
time in the world.

That was the most exciting
thing I’ve ever done.

And he always said, I guess
I shouldn’t have taken you
to Disney World, then.
Running makes me feel alive.
I love it.
I absolutely love it.

Before I felt ready to compete
as a woman in competitive

races, I needed to be certain
that my years as a biological

male didn’t give me
an unfair advantage.

We don’t have
unequivocal science yet.

So I started logging
my own times.

I’ve kept careful records of
my times and rankings since

Despite more than three
years of hormone therapy,

I’m now relatively faster as
a woman than I was as a man.

I’m following
all of the rules.
And I don’t know what to do.

It could be for any
number of reasons.

Since I’ve transitioned, I’m
happier, and I’ve been able
to train better.

Or it could be
because my body helps

me retain some
athletic advantage
over biological women.
It makes me uncomfortable.

I’m mostly figuring
this out on my own.

So for now, my compromise is
I compete as a female but only

in races where I know I won’t
make the medal podium or win
money.

As a competitor,
I want to win.

But I only want to win
if I know it’s fair.

I exist in this
chasm between those

who believe I am a cheater
who is hurting women

and those who insist
that merely identifying

as a woman is a right
to compete as a woman.

I want to urge both
sides to please

stop using this issue for your
own politics and podcasts.

Of course I long
for inclusion.

Of course I want to
compete fully as a woman.

I don’t know where the line
between fair and unfair

advantage falls, but I do
know I want to make these

decisions based on
science and not beliefs,

which includes accepting
the possibility that I might
still retain an advantage.

Put your politics aside
and let science speak.
